scenario:
Bank of America makes up almost 11.3% of Berkshire Hathaway's portfolio and has shown resilience and financial fortitude despite macroeconomic challenges. The bank has demonstrated strength in consumer banking, wealth management, global banking, and merger and acquisition business lines. Analysts expect revenue and earnings per share to be $25.1 billion and $0.77, respectively, in the fourth quarter of 2024, with a 14.3% year-over-year revenue jump and a 133% earnings jump. Net interest income is expected to continue growing, reaching $14.3 billion in the fourth quarter of 2024. The bank has successfully managed its deposit relationships and is making rapid strides in digitization. Despite this positive picture, the stock is trading at just 1.26 times its book value, a very reasonable multiple. Berkshire Hathaway sold nearly 235 million shares of the company in 2024, but still owns just under 10% of the bank.

American Express has emerged as a compelling pick in 2025 due to its premium customer base and optimal execution capabilities. The company delivered strong results in Q3 2024, with earnings per share of $3.49, despite a 6% year-over-year rise in billings. American Express raised its earnings guidance for 2024 from $13.30 to $13.80 to a new range of $13.75 to $14.05. The company's credit quality is impressive, with a 1.9% write-off rate in Q3, and its solid risk management is evident in its robust reserve rate of 2.9%. American Express is successful with younger customers, with spending across millennial and Gen Z accounts growing 12% year over year in the third quarter. The company is also focused on a product refresh strategy, enhancing existing products with new benefits and services. Despite a premium customer base, loyal younger clientele, and robust product refresh strategy, American Express stock trades at just 3 times sales, making it an attractive buy in 2025.
